State Law reference- Minnesota Emergency Management Act of 1996, Minn. Stats. ch. 12. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-22, §§ 2, 3, adopted July 22, 2008, repealed former Art. II, §§ 14-19-14-26, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1978, § 7.28 and Ord. No. 89-07, adopted April 25, 1989. 

Sec. 14-19. - Purpose. 
    The city council deems it necessary to provide for the special and express regulation of alarm systems which are designed to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which public safety personnel are expected to respond in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare. The regulation is necessary in order to reduce the increasing frequency of false alarms in the city. The great number and increasing frequency of these false alarms requires intensive, time-consuming efforts by the police department and fire department and thereby distracts from and reduces the level of services available to the rest of the community. This diminishes the ability of the city to promote the general health, welfare and safety of the community. In consideration for the necessity on the part of the city to provide numerous public safety services in one area to work to the detriment of members of the general public, it is hereby decided that the alarm systems shall be regulated by a penalty process. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 3, 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 14-20. - Definitions. 
    Alarm or alarm system means a single device or assembly of devices operating mechanically, electronically or by means of radio frequency method such as cellular or private radio signal indicating the need for a response by emergency personnel or services. Such signals emitted may be audible or may be transmitted to some receiving site for the purpose of notification of the need for an emergency response. This definition includes personal panic alarms. The provisions of this ordinance are not applicable to alarm systems affixed to automobiles, boat trailers, house trailers, and recreational motor vehicles. 
    Alarm user means the person, firm partnership, association, cooperative, company or organization of any kind in control of any building, structure, or facility wherein an alarm system is maintained. 
    Anoka County Central Communications is the facility operated by the County of Anoka, State of Minnesota to receive emergency requests for service and general information from the public to be dispatched to respective public safety units. 
    Calendar year shall mean the period January 1 through December 31 of each year. 
    Cancelled alarm means an alarm that is cancelled prior to unit arrival, and is not considered a "false alarm." 
    False alarm means an alarm signal eliciting a response by public safety personnel when a situation requiring a response does not, in fact, exist, and which is caused by the activation of the alarm system through mechanical failure, alarm malfunction, intentional acts, improper installation or the inadvertence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or their employees, agents or of a third party. Alarms activated by conditions such as snow, rain, mist, or fog are considered false alarms for the purposes of this section, but do not include alarms caused by severe climatic conditions such as tornadoes, thunderstorms, utility line mishaps, or other violent conditions of nature. 
    Public safety personnel means the law enforcement and fire department officers of the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 3, 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 14-21. - Penalties for false alarms. 
    Upon receipt and determination of repeat false alarms, the following penalties shall be imposed: 
(1)  Administrative civil penalties. 
a.  For the third false alarm in a calendar year, the administrative civil penalty as established by council ordinance shall be imposed. 
b.  For the fourth false alarm in a calendar year, the administrative civil penalty as established by council ordinance shall be imposed. 
c.  For the fifth false alarm in a calendar year, the administrative civil penalty as established by council ordinance shall be imposed. 
d.  For the sixth false alarm in a calendar year, the administrative civil penalty as established by council ordinance shall be imposed, and the alarm user must provide a plan of action to correct, replace or remove the alarm system. A written plan of action must be submitted to the police or fire chief within ten days of notice to the alarm user. All plans will be reviewed and must receive approval by the police or fire chief. 
(2)  Misdemeanor criminal penalties. 
a.  An alarm user that fails to pay an administrative civil penalty per subsection 14-21(1) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
b.  An alarm user that fails to receive approval for a written plan of action per subsection 14-21(1)d. shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 3, 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 14-22. - Assessment. 
    Unpaid civil penalties shall be certified as an assessment against the property on which the alarm was located. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 3, 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 14-23. - Duration. 
    For the purposes of this section, any accrued false alarms will expire at the end of each calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 3, 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 14-24. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Alarms cancelled prior to unit arrival will not be considered a false alarm. 
(b)  False alarms will be excused, and shall not be accrued toward the two alarm limit, during the 60-day period after the initial installation of an alarm system at a location. 
(c)  False alarms will also be excused if they are a result of an effort or order to upgrade, install, test or maintain an alarm system and if the police or fire department is given adequate notice in advance of said upgrade, installation, testing and maintenance. 
(d)  A business or residence with two or more separate alarm systems shall be treated as having one system in reference to the amount of false alarms permitted prior to being penalized. 
(e)  Certain entities exempt. The United States Government, State of Minnesota, City of Ramsey, or any departments thereof, are exempt from the penalties stated above. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 3, 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 14-25. - Appeal process. 
    An alarm user that is required to pay a penalty as a result of false alarms may make a written appeal within ten days of notice by the city of the false alarm charge to the chief of police. The police or fire chief will then review the appeal for possible dismissal of the false alarm charge. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 3, 7-22-2008) 
Sec. 14-26. - Prohibitions. 
    No person shall install, monitor or use and possess an operative alarm which utilizes taped or prerecorded messages which deliver a telephone alarm message to the Anoka County Communication Center or the city police or fire departments directly or via city administration lines. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 3, 7-22-2008) 
Chapter 18 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Environment generally, Minn. Stats. chs. 114C-116L. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPEN BURNING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Open burning, Minn. Stats. § 88.171. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Open burning means the burning of any matter if the resultant combustion products are emitted directly to the atmosphere without passing through a stack, duct or chimney, except a recreational fire. 
    Recreational fire means a fire set with approved starter fuel no more than three feet in height, contained within the border of a recreational fire site using dry, clean wood; producing little detectable smoke, odor or soot beyond the property line; conducted with an adult tending the fire at all times; for recreational, ceremonial, food preparation or social purposes; extinguished completely before quitting the occasion; and respecting weather conditions, neighbors, burning bans, and air quality so that nuisance, health or safety hazards will not be created. Mobile cooking devices such as manufactured hibachis, charcoal grills, wood smokers and propane or natural gas devices are not defined as recreational fires. 
    Recreational fire site means an area of no more than a three-foot diameter circle (measured from the inside of the fire ring or border); completely surrounded by non-combustible and non-smoke- or odor-producing material, either of natural rock, cement, brick, tile or blocks or ferrous metal only and which area is depressed below ground, on the ground, or on a raised bed. Included are permanent outdoor woodburning fireplaces. Burning barrels are prohibited and are not a recreational fire site as defined herein. Recreational fire sites shall not be located closer than 50 feet to any structure. 
    Starter fuels means dry, untreated, unpainted kindling, branches, or cardboard, or charcoal fire starter. Paraffin candles and alcohols are permitted as starter fuels and as aids to ignition only. Propane gas torches or other clean gas burning devices causing minimal pollution must be used to start an open burn. 
    Wood means dry, clean fuel only such as twigs, branches, limbs, "presto logs," charcoal, cord wood or untreated dimensional lumber. "Wood" does not include wood that is green, with leaves or needles, rotten, wet, oil soaked, or treated with paint, glue or preservatives. Clean pallets may be used for recreational fires when cut into three-foot lengths. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.02; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-20. - Provisions adopted by reference. 
    The provisions of Minn. Stats. §§ 88.16 and 88.17 and Minnesota State Fire Code (where adopted), are adopted by reference and made a part of this Code as if fully set forth at this point. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.12; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-21. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish permitted categories of open burn events for residences and farms within the city and provide for a permitting process for residential and agricultural open burning, except when such open burning is defined as a "recreational fire" as prescribed in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.01; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-22. - Prohibited materials. 
(a)  No person shall conduct, cause or permit open burning of oils, petroleum fuels, rubber, plastics, chemically treated materials, or other materials which produce excessive or noxious smoke such as tires, railroad ties, treated, painted or glued wood, composite shingles, tar paper, insulation, composition board, sheetrock, wiring, paint or paint fillers. 
(b)  No person shall conduct, cause or permit open burning of hazardous waste or salvage operations, or open burning of solid waste generated from an industrial or manufacturing process or from a service or commercial establishment or building material generated from demolition of commercial or institutional structures. No person shall conduct, cause or permit open burning of discarded material resulting from the handling, processing, storage, preparation, serving or consumption of food. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.03; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-23. - Burning ban or air quality alert. 
    No recreational fire or open burn will be permitted when the city or DNR has officially declared a burning ban due to potentially hazardous fire conditions or when the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA) has declared an Air Quality Alert. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.11; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Secs. 18-24-18-49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 18-50. - Required. 
    No person shall start or allow any open burning on any property in the city without first having obtained an open burn permit, except that a permit is not required for any fire that is a recreational fire as defined herein. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.04; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-51. - Application burning and fees. 
(a)  Open burning permits shall be obtained by making application on a form prescribed by the department of natural resources (DNR) and Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA) and adopted by the city. The permit application shall be presented to the fire chief or designee for reviewing and processing said applications. 
(b)  An open burning permit shall require a nonrefundable application fee. In the event the open burning permit application is approved, the permit fee shall be volume based. Application and permit fees shall be set by ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.06; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-52. - Issuance process. 
    Upon receipt of the completed open burning permit application and permit fee, the fire chief or designee shall schedule a preliminary site inspection to locate the proposed burn site, draft a fire event safety plan, and note special conditions. The materials to be burned may then be piled for burning at which time a second inspection shall be scheduled to assess volume of material and associated fees, set dates and times of permitted burn and review fire safety considerations. Two days before burning, the permit holder shall notify the city fire department of the proposed burn. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.07; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-53. - Issuance standards. 
(a)  Open burn permits may be issued only for the following purposes: 
(1)  Elimination of fire or health hazard that cannot be abated by other practical means. 
(2)  Ground thawing for utility repair and construction. 
(3)  Disposal of vegetative matter for managing forest, prairie or wildlife habitat, and in the development and maintenance of land and rights-of-way where chipping, composting, land spreading or other alternative methods are not practical. 
(4)  Disposal of diseased trees generated on site, diseased or infected nursery stock, and diseased bee hives. 
(5)  Disposal of unpainted, untreated, non-glued lumber and wood shakes generated from construction, where recycling, reuse, removal or other alternative disposal methods are not practical. 
(b)  Fire training permits can only be issued by the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA). No fire may be allowed to smolder with no flame present. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.05; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-54. - Denial. 
    If established criteria for the issuance of an open burning permit are not met, or if during review of said application it is determined that a practical alternative method for disposal of the material exists, or a pollution or nuisance condition would result, or if a burn event safety plan cannot be drafted to the satisfaction of the fire chief or designee, the fire chief or designee may deny the application for the open burning permit. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.10; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-55. - Permit holder responsibility. 
(a)  Prior to starting an open burn, the permit holder shall be responsible for confirming that no burning ban or air quality alert is in effect. Every open burn event shall be constantly attended by the permit holder or his competent representative. The open burning site shall have available, appropriate communication and fire suppression equipment as set out in the fire safety plan. The open burn fire shall be completely extinguished before the permit holder or his representative leaves the site. It is the responsibility of the permit holder to have a valid permit, as required by this article, available for inspection on the site by the city police department, fire department, Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA) representative, and/or department of natural resources (DNR) forest officer. 
(b)  The permit holder is responsible for compliance and implementation of all general conditions, special conditions and the burn event safety plan as established in the permit issued. The permit holder shall be responsible for all costs incurred as a result of the burn, including, but not limited to, fire suppression and administrative fees. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.08; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Sec. 18-56. - Revocation. 
    The open burning permit is subject to revocation at the discretion of the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA) commissioner, or department of natural resources (DNR) forest officer, or the fire chief or designee. Reasons for revocation include, but are not limited to: a fire hazard existing or developing during the course of the burn, any of the conditions of the permit being violated during the course of the burn, pollution or nuisance conditions developing during the course of the burn, or a fire smoldering with no flame present. 
(Code 1978, § 7.83.09; Ord. No. 92-03, 4-13-1992) 
Chapter 22 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General authority relative to fire prevention, Minn. Stats. §§ 410.33, 412.221, subd. 17; fire safety generally, Minn. Stats. ch. 299F. 

Sec. 22-1. - Fire department. 
(a)  Creation. There is established in the city a fire department consisting of paid on-call staff and full-time staff. 
(b)  Purpose. The fire department shall be established for the purpose of the protection of lives and property within the city from fire and other property or life threatening emergencies. The fire department shall provide fire prevention services in accordance with those general policies established by the council. 
(Code 1978, § 3.15) 
Sec. 22-2. - Minnesota State Fire Code adopted by reference. 
    Subject to any amendments made by the city, the 2007 Minnesota State Fire Code (MSFC) including Appendixes A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H and J is adopted by reference as the city fire code. Such code adopts by reference the International Fire Code (IFC) promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials and the Western Fire Chiefs Association. One copy of the MSFC and the IFC will be retained on file in the city administrator's office. 
State Law reference- Minnesota State Fire Code, Minn. Stats. § 299F.011; adoption by reference, Minn. Stats. § 471.62. 
Chapter 26 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES AND PERMITS GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business, trade or profession includes the bartering, selling, purchasing or exchange of goods, services and materials, with or without compensation. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.02; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-20. - Compliance. 
    No person shall practice or carry on a business, trade or profession in the city without complying with all federal and state regulations, laws, license or permit requirements, and with the license and permit requirements of any provision of this Code. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.01; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
State Law reference- Businesses that violate ordinances, Minn. Stats. § 415.17. 
Sec. 26-21. - Application. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this article, application for any license or permit required by this article shall be made with the city clerk on forms furnished by the city. The applicant shall provide such information as required by the city or any licensing or permit provision of this Code. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.03; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-22. - Processing time. 
    The minimum length of time required for the processing of any application shall be determined by the city clerk and he shall inform any applicant of the appropriate time requirements. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.04; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-23. - Term. 
    The license or permit term shall be January 1 to December 31 of each year, unless otherwise provided in this Code. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.05; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-24. - Renewal. 
    No license or permit is automatically renewed by the city. Applications for renewal shall be submitted to the city clerk prior to the expiration date for the council's approval or for approval by its designated representative. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.06; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-25. - Proration and refunds. 
    No license or permit fee shall be refunded except as expressly provided in this article. Upon revocation of a license or permit the licensee or permittee shall not be given any refund of the fee paid for the license or permit. License and permit fees may be prorated based on the number of months remaining in the then calendar year. Proration shall apply only to those applicants who have not held a license in the city during the previous calendar year. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.07; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-26. - Revocation. 
    Any violation of the terms of this article or any other licensing or permit provision of this article shall be grounds for suspension and/or revocation of the license or permit by the council. Licenses and permits shall be revoked only for cause and upon adequate notice and the opportunity to be heard. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.08; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-27. - Display. 
    Any person to whom a license or permit is issued pursuant to this article shall be required to display such license or permit or to make said license or permit available for review upon request. This provision shall be subordinate to any other provision of this article that expressly requires that said license or permit shall be displayed or posted. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.09; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-28. - Fees. 
    The various license and permit fees required by this article shall be those license fees as set from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 7.01.10; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975; Ord. No. 91-08, 6-30-1991) 
Secs. 26-29-26-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUSINESS REGISTRATION CERTIFICATE 

Sec. 26-60. - Definitions. 
    City Code section 117-1 (definitions) is hereby incorporated into this article. 
(Code 1978, § 7.20.01, subd. 2; Ord. No. 03-12, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 04-45, 12-27-2004; Ord. No. 13-24, § 2, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 26-61. - Violation. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article is guilty of a petty misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 7.20.01, subd. 6; Ord. No. 03-12, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 04-45, 12-27-2004) 
Sec. 26-62. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish a process for the city to obtain and maintain current information on all businesses located in the city. The obtained information will allow the city to be informed as to current occupancy and occupancy changes within buildings, permit the city to update and review records regarding emergency contact lists, fire preplan, inspection, and hazardous materials. The information will permit the city to verify that any business intending to operate within the city shall comply with the state building code, the state fire code, and local Code requirements. The city police department will be notified of any hazards or security issues that may affect the community's health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1978, § 7.20.01, subd. 1; Ord. No. 03-12, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 04-45, 12-27-2004) 
Sec. 26-63. - General requirements. 
(a)  Certificate. No person or entity shall operate any business in the city without first obtaining a business registration certificate (BRC) issued by the city. 
(b)  Application. The applicant shall provide such information as required on forms furnished by the city. The completed form shall be submitted to the city. The application shall be filed with the city 30 days prior to any business's intended occupancy, or 30 days prior to the existing BRC's expiration date. 
(c)  Term. A BRC shall be effective from January 1 to December 31 of each year, unless otherwise provided in this Code. 
(d)  Renewal. No BRC shall be automatically renewed. Applications for renewal shall be submitted to the zoning administrator prior to the BRC's expiration date. 
(e)  Display. Any person to whom a BRC is issued pursuant to this article shall be required to display the BRC at the business or entity in public view. 
(f)  Fees. The BRC fee required shall be established by ordinance. When an existing BRC holder changes its name but does not substantially change its business operations, the applicant shall reapply for a new BRC, however no additional BRC fee shall be required. Any business licensed under the provisions of this Code shall be exempt from such fee. 
(Code 1978, § 7.20.01, subd. 3; Ord. No. 03-12, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 04-45, 12-27-2004; Ord. No. 13-24, § 2, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 26-64. - Required application information. 
(a)  The application for a BRC shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name of proposed business. 
(2)  Address of business (including suite number, if applicable). 
(3)  Phone number of business. 
(4)  Business fax. 
(5)  Business website/email address. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(7)  Key holder contact information. 
(8)  Type of business operation. 
(9)  Building owner's name, address, and phone numbers. 
(10)  Amount of flammable/combustible liquid storage on the business site. 
(11)  Amount of hazardous materials storage on the business site. 
(12)  Amount of explosive material or ammunition on the business site. 
(13)  Reserved. 
(14)  Hours of operation. 
(15)  Name of alarm company serving the business site. 
(16)  Reserved. 
(17)  Type of alarm system on the business site (water flow, burglar, glass break). 
(18)  Any other information the city may find necessary to accomplish the purpose of this article. 
(b)  Applications must be returned to the zoning administrator within 30 days of receipt of the application. Applicants who do not return application within the required time period will be considered in violation of this article and will be subject to prosecution in accordance with section 26-61. 
(Code 1978, § 7.20.01, subd. 4; Ord. No. 03-12, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 04-45, 12-27-2004; Ord. No. 13-24, § 2, 11-12-2013) 
Sec. 26-65. - Issuance of business registration certificate. 
    Upon completion and approval of the following, the city will issue a BRC to the business: 
(1)  Receipt of a complete BRC application; 
(2)  City review of the BRC application; and 
(3)  Verification that the business complies with this Code, state building code, and the state fire code. 
(Code 1978, § 7.20.01, subd. 5; Ord. No. 03-12, 6-2-2003; Ord. No. 04-45, 12-27-2004) 
Secs. 26-66-26-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CARNIVALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-89. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement ride means a mechanical device that carries or conveys passengers along, around, or over a fixed or restricted route or course for the purpose of giving its passengers amusement, pleasure, thrills or excitement. 
    Carnival means an aggregation of attractions, whether shows, acts, games, vending devices or amusement machines, whether conducted under one or more managements or independent, which are temporarily set up or conducted in a public place or on any private premises accessible to the public with or without an admission fee including, but not limited to, circuses, speed tests, endurance tests and any other attractions or devices which, from the nature of the aggregation, attract attendance of the public for their entertainment and pleasure. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.01) 
Sec. 26-90. - Operation. 
(a)  The operator or owner of the carnival regulated hereunder shall conduct said operations and premises in conformance with all laws and regulations of the city and the state. No alcoholic beverages shall be permitted on the premises of the operation without the appropriate liquor license. 
(b)  The operator or owner shall control traffic entering and leaving said premises so that there is no interference with the orderly flow of traffic on the public streets adjacent thereto. 
(c)  The city council shall establish such conditions as are deemed appropriate to provide for the cleaning of the premises and all other properties relating to the operation within a reasonable period after the event and may require a deposit fee in an amount established by ordinance, to guarantee such cleaning. Said deposit will be refunded upon satisfactory cleanup as determined by the city clerk or his designee. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.09) 
Secs. 26-91-26-108. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 26-109. - Required. 
    No person shall operate, maintain, or conduct any carnival within the city without first procuring a license as provided herein. All carnivals are restricted to a time period not to exceed 14 days total. Any event defined as a "carnival" herein that is regulated by a conditional use permit, or any carnival for the purpose of raising funds for the benefit of a fraternal, religious, veteran or educational organization having its principal meeting place or school within the city shall not be required to obtain a license if no amusement rides regulated by Minn. Stats. ch. 184B will used at the carnival. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.02) 
Sec. 26-110. - Application. 
    An application for such license shall be made in writing to the city clerk or his designee and shall state the full name and address of the applicant, the location where the carnival is to be conducted, the owner of the premises, the days on which the carnival is to be conducted, and other such information as shall be required by the city. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.03) 
Sec. 26-111. - Review and approval. 
    The information in the application will be investigated as required by the city. The applicant shall provide evidence of written permission for the operation of the carnival from the owner of the location of the premises. The city council shall require review and recommendation from the fire chief, police chief and community development director, and upon satisfactory recommendation the city council will approve said license. The city council reserves the right to require a public hearing on the application and such hearings shall be held at such time and upon such notice as the council may determine. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.04) 
Sec. 26-112. - Conditions. 
    The council may impose any conditions or restrictions it deems necessary or advisable to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, including but not limited to conditions relating to the hours of operations, the lighting of the premises and the parking facilities. The council may impose any conditions or restrictions at any time after the issuance of a license hereunder. A bond may be required in such form and amount as specified by the council to guarantee compliance with any conditions that shall be herein imposed. The license shall permit operation of the circus or carnival only on the days specified in the application. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.05) 
Sec. 26-113. - License fees. 
    A nonrefundable application fee shall be established by ordinance and shall be paid at the time the application is submitted to the city. The fee for the license shall be established by ordinance and the fee shall be paid at the time the license is issued. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.06) 
Sec. 26-114. - Insurance. 
(a)  The licensee shall obtain and keep in full force and effect proper liability insurance coverage to protect the city and said licensee against any claims or liability for personal injury or property damage sustained by any persons as a result of the operation of said circus or carnival. The liability insurance coverage shall name the city as an additional insured, and said insurance shall be an all-perils or general liability policy in the minimum amount of $1,000,000.00 issued by a company authorized to do business in the state. The policy shall require that the city be notified 30 days in advance of cancellation of the policy. 
(b)  Said licensee shall obtain and keep in full force and effect proper insurance coverage against any liability for injury sustained by any persons operating said license activities as required under the provisions of the Workers' Compensation Act of the state. 
(c)  Said licensee shall submit to the city clerk satisfactory certificates of insurance for the coverage required herein prior to issuance of an approved license. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.07) 
Sec. 26-115. - Indemnification. 
    The licensee shall, indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the city from any claims and any liability in whatsoever manner arising, which may be brought against the municipality, as the result of the operation of the carnival. Indemnification shall be provided to the city in writing prior to issuance of an approved license. 
(Code 1978, § 7.14.08) 
Secs. 26-116-26-143. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CHARITABLE GAMBLING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Lawful gambling, Minn. Stats. ch. 349; local authority relative to lawful gambling, Minn. Stats. § 349.213. 

Sec. 26-144. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board means the state gambling control board. 
    Lawful gambling means the operation of gambling activities by an organization eligible for a license from the board to conduct such activities. 
    Net profits , lawful purpose , and allowable expense will have the meanings provided in Minn. Stats. § 349.12 as may be amended from time to time. 
    Organization means as defined by Minn. Stats. § 349.12 and which organization is licensed to conduct lawful gambling by the board. 
    Premises permit means a resolution adopted by the city council authorizing the named organization to operate lawful gambling activities at a specified location in the city. 
    Trade area includes the Cities of Ramsey, Anoka, Andover, Elk River, Dayton and Nowthen. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.02; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007; Ord. No. 08-28, § 2, 10-28-2008) 
State Law reference- Definitions, Minn. Stats. § 349.12. 
Sec. 26-145. - Violations. 
    Anyone who violates the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. This article does not preclude civil and criminal penalties under applicable laws. Failure to file timely reports and payments as required by this article may result in a recommendation to the board that the organization's premises permit should be revoked. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.11; Ord. No. 07-09, § 3, 6-28-2007) 
Sec. 26-146. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to regulate and control the location of lawful gambling activities and to ensure that profits derived from gambling activities in the city provide, to the extent authorized by law, direct benefits to the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.01; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007) 
Sec. 26-147. - Notice; approval or disapproval. 
    The applicant for a lawful gambling premises permit ("premises permit") within the city shall apply to the council in writing in the manner required by law for a premises permit at least 60 days before issuing or renewing the premises permit. Each application for a premises permit shall be approved or disapproved by the council. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.03; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007) 
State Law reference- Premises permits, Minn. Stats. § 349.165; local approval of premises permits, Minn. Stats. § 349.213m, subd. 2; local investigation fees for premises permits, Minn. Stats. § 349.16, subd. 8. 
Sec. 26-148. - Location. 
(a)  Lawful gambling under license issued by the state gambling control board ("board") may be conducted only at locations that comply with applicable zoning, building, fire and health codes of the city. All applications must be for a specific location with the exception of Class D (raffle only) licenses. 
(b)  The following locations are considered unsuitable for gambling operations and any request for a premises permit at such a location will be rejected without clear and convincing evidence that such a location will not pose undue enforcement difficulties, lessen property values of adjoining properties, or expose gambling to persons under 18 years of age: 
(1)  Areas zoned for agriculture or residential use; 
(2)  Locations where the predominant clientele is under the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.04; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007) 
Sec. 26-149. - Conditions. 
    The conduct of lawful gambling under license issued by the board shall be subject to the following conditions in the city: 
(1)  Lease agreement. A copy of any lease agreement between a nonprofit organization and a gambling location owner or operator shall be filed with the city administrator together with the premises permit application. 
(2)  Refusal of permit. The council may refuse to issue a premises permit for a location in which gambling violations have previously occurred, and the council may refuse to issue a lawful gambling premises permit to a nonprofit organization which has previously violated terms of this Code and/or Minn. Stats. ch. 349. 
(3)  Number of devices. The maximum number of gambling devices at any one location in the city shall be limited to two of any one type of device. The maximum number of each gambling device may be operated by any one or more than one organization holding a premises permit at any one location. 
(4)  Location of organization. The physical site for the organization's place of doing business shall be located within the corporate limits of either the City of Ramsey or the City of Anoka. In addition, the organization's place of doing business all have been located within either the City of Ramsey or the City of Anoka for at least two years immediately preceding the premises permit application. During the term of the premises permit, the organization's place of business shall continuously be located within the corporate limits of either the City of Ramsey or the City of Anoka. 
(5)  Resident requirement. For organizations located within the City of Anoka, at least 50 percent of said organization's membership or participants shall be residents of the City of Ramsey. Said residency requirement shall be documented upon issuance and renewal of the premises permit by the organization presenting its certified roster or membership list to the City of Ramsey for its review 30 days prior to expiration of the premises permit. 
(6)  Grandfathering provision. Those organizations that hold a premises permit issued prior to July 29, 2007, will be considered "grandfathered in" as concerns the location of organization requirements identified in subsection (1) of this section. The city reserves the right to delete this subsection (6) and terminate this grandfathering provision. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.05; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007; Ord. No. 08-28, § 2, 10-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-150. - Investigation. 
    Every organization that files an application for issuance or renewal of a premises permit shall deliver the application to the city clerk. The city clerk shall investigate each application and report any findings and recommendations to the council. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.06; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007) 
Sec. 26-151. - Filing of records; inspections; access to records. 
(a)  Every organization holding a premises permit to conduct lawful gambling in the city shall file with the city clerk copies of all records and reports required to be filed with the board pursuant to Minn. Stats. ch. 349 and the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. In addition, an organization that operates lawful gambling activities in other communities must provide separate documentation showing the gross receipts, expenses, profits, and expenditures of profits from its city operation alone. The records and reports shall be filed in the office of the city clerk on or before the day they are required to be filed with the board. 
(b)  Every gambling event in the city conducted by an organization under Minn. Stats. ch. 349 shall be open to inspection by officers of the city police department. 
(c)  The city clerk or employees of the police department, at the direction of the city clerk, may inspect at any reasonable time, without notice or search warrant, all records of an organization holding a premises permit in the city, including gambling account and other bank records required by the board to be maintained and preserved. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.07; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007) 
Sec. 26-152. - Fee. 
    The city will charge all new applicants the maximum investigation fee permitted by Minn. Stats. ch. 349 in order to cover costs incurred investigating the application. Any unused portion of this fee will be refunded to the applicant. This fee does not apply to applications for renewal of premises permits or additional sites for an organization currently holding a premises permit in the city. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.08; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007) 
State Law reference- Investigation fee authorized, Minn. Stats. § 349.16, subd. 8. 
Sec. 26-153. - Use of lawful gambling net profits. 
    Any organization that holds a premises permit shall be required to contribute five percent of its net profits from lawful gambling to a fund administered and regulated by the city without cost to such fund. In no event shall the required percent be greater than that amount allowed by Minn. Stats. ch. 349. Disbursements from this fund shall be for lawful purposes as determined by ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.09; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority to so require, Minn. Stats. § 349.213, subd. 1(a). 
Sec. 26-154. - Expenditures for lawful purposes within city's trade area. 
(a)  Any organization holding a premises permit to conduct lawful gambling within the city shall be required to expend 75 percent of its lawful purpose expenditures on lawful purposes conducted or located within the city's trade area and to the benefit of the city's trade area. 
(b)  A detailed quarterly report of the expenditures for lawful purposes within the trade area shall be provided to the finance officer on or before January 15, April 15, July 15 and October 15 of each year after the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived. Any organization that fails to submit a detailed quarterly lawful purpose expenditure report of how the required 75 percent was expended will be brought before city council to discuss possible future revocation of their premises permit. 
(c)  In the event the city is unable to determine with a reasonable degree of certainty that the required 75 percent of the lawful purpose expenditures of the organization holding a premises permit to conduct lawful gambling within the city's trade area is being expended on lawful purposes, the city administrator may require such other financial information as is reasonably necessary for the city to make this determination. 
(Code 1978, § 7.61.10; Ord. No. 94-05, 7-27-1994; Ord. No. 07-09, § 2, 6-28-2007) 
State Law reference- Authority to so require, Minn. Stats. § 349.213, subd. 1(b). 
Secs. 26-155-26-176. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTORS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Electricians, Minn. Stats. § 326B.31 et seq.; plumbers, Minn. Stats. § 326B.41 et seq.; residential building contractors, Minn. Stats. § 326B.801 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-177. - Construction. 
    It is deemed in the interest of the public and the residents of the city that the work involved in building alteration and construction and the installation of various appliances and service facilities in and for said buildings be done only by individuals, firms and corporations that have demonstrated or submitted evidence of their competency to perform such work in accordance with the applicable sections of this Code regulating same. 
(Code 1978, § 7.03, subd. 1; Ord. No. 05-16, 9-12-2005) 
Sec. 26-178. - Licensing by city; exceptions. 
(a)  Contractors licensed. The permits which the building official is authorized to issue under this Code shall be issued only to individuals, firms, or corporations holding a license by the city for work to be performed under the permit, except as hereinafter noted. 
(b)  State-licensed contractors excepted. Those persons who possess valid licenses issued by the state shall not be required to obtain a license from the city; they shall, however, be required to file proof of the existence of a valid license together with proof of satisfactory workers' compensation insurance coverage, provided said work is covered under the scope of the state license. 
(c)  Public service corporations excepted. Public service corporations shall not be required to obtain licenses for work upon, or in connection with, their own property except as may be provided by other sections. 
(d)  Manufacturers excepted. Manufacturers shall not be required to obtain licenses for work incorporated within equipment as a part of manufacturing except as may be provided by other sections of this Code. 
(Code 1978, § 7.03, subds. 2, 8-10; Ord. No. 05-16, 9-12-2005) 
State Law reference- Electricians, Minn. Stats. § 326B.31 et seq.; plumbers, Minn. Stats. § 326B.41 et seq.; residential building contractors, Minn. Stats. § 326B.801 et seq. 
Sec. 26-179. - Permit to owners. 
    The owner of any property may perform work on property that they occupy, so long as the work when performed is in accordance with this Code, and for such purpose, a permit may be granted to such owner without a license obtained. 
(Code 1978, § 7.03, subd. 7; Ord. No. 05-16, 9-12-2005) 
Secs. 26-180-26-196. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 26-197. - Specific trades licensed. 
    Licenses shall be obtained by every person engaging in the following businesses or work in accordance with the applicable section of this Code: 
(1)  General contractors in the business of building construction. Exempted from this general contractor licensing requirement shall be any individual who applies to the city for a permit to build a home to be occupied by themselves. However, if the same individual makes another application to build another home to be occupied by themselves within two years from the date of the first building permit application, a general contracting license shall then be required for any structure built within the two-year period; 
(2)  General construction including erection, alteration or repair of buildings; (commercial construction); 
(3)  Heating, air conditioning, ventilation and refrigeration; 
(4)  Sewer and water connections between street connection and property line; 
(5)  Water supply system installation and construction; 
(6)  Excavations, including excavation for footings, basements, grading of lots, sewer and water line installation, etc.; 
(7)  Cement contractors and block layers. Nothing here shall be construed as preventing any such qualified licensee from performing the work by an employee under his supervision and control, or by contract with another person qualified to perform the same, provided the contractor is subject to the control of the licensee and the licensee is at all times responsible for the work performed; 
(8)  The moving and wrecking of buildings; 
(9)  Plastering, outside stucco work or lathing; 
(10)  Gas installation, including heating, appliances, devices or machinery, etc.; 
(11)  Siding; 
(12)  Sign and billboard erecting; 
(13)  Swimming pool installers; 
(14)  Septic tank and cesspool pumping; 
(15)  Lawn irrigation installers; 
(16)  Pole barn, barn construction including erection, alteration or repair of buildings. 
(Code 1978, § 7.03, subd. 6; Ord. No. 05-16, 9-12-2005) 
Sec. 26-198. - Assumption of liability. 
    This article shall not be construed to affect the responsibility of any party owning, operating, controlling or installing the work described in section 26-197 for damages to persons or property caused by any defect therein nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of the licensing of persons, firms or corporations engaged in such work. 
(Code 1978, § 7.03, subd. 11; Ord. No. 05-16, 9-12-2005) 
Sec. 26-199. - Requirements. 
    Application for license shall be made to the building official and such license shall be granted upon proof of the applicant's qualifications therefor, his willingness to comply with the provisions of this Code, the filing of certificates evidencing the holding of public liability insurance in the form of general liability or all-perils insurance in the amount of at least $1,000,000.00. Such policy shall name the city as an additional insured and shall require that the city be notified 30 days in advance of cancellation of the policy. Any person aggrieved by the building official's refusal to issue a license may appeal the building official's decision to the council, which shall then review the building official's decision and either affirm or reverse said decision. 
(Code 1978, § 7.03, subd. 3; Ord. No. 05-16, 9-12-2005) 
Sec. 26-200. - Fee. 
    All contractors' licenses shall be obtained from the building official. Applications for licenses shall be filed with the building official on the forms furnished by the city. The fee for each license shall be as set by ordinance and shall not be refunded or prorated. The annual license fee and expiration date shall be as referenced in section 26-28, except that no license shall be required for: 
(1)  Plumbing work that entails the installation within a building of the pipes, fittings, and fixtures that carry water and waste; 
(2)  Electrical construction and installation; 
(3)  Water conditioning servicing and installation; 
(4)  Water supply installation and construction (well drillers); 
provided that the applicant for any of these licenses presents for filing a copy of his license issued by the appropriate state regulatory board. 
(Code 1978, § 7.03, subd. 4; Ord. No. 05-16, 9-12-2005) 
Sec. 26-201. - Expiration. 
    All licenses issued under this Code shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance. If a license is granted hereunder and is not renewed prior to expiration then all rights granted by such license shall cease and any work performed after the expiration of the license shall be in violation of this Code. All licenses are subject to revocation or forfeiture prior to the expiration date. 
(Code 1978, § 7.03, subd. 5; Ord. No. 05-16, 9-12-2005) 
Secs. 26-202-26-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FIREWORKS SALES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Fireworks, Minn. Stats. § 624.20 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-226. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Legal fireworks means wire or wood sparklers of not more than 100 grams of mixture per item, other sparkling items which are non-explosive and non-aerial and contain 75 grams or less of chemical mixture per tube or a total of 200 grams or less for multiple tubes, snakes and glow worms, smoke devices, or trick noisemakers which include paper streamers, party poppers, string poppers, snappers, and drop pops, each consisting of not more than 0.25 gram of explosive mixture. 
(Code 1978, § 7.86.01, subd. 2; Ord. No. 02-21, 7-22-2002) 
Sec. 26-227. - Sale of fireworks. 
    It is unlawful to sell fireworks in the city, in violation of Minn. Stats. §§ 624.20-624.25, which statutes are adopted by reference. The term "legal fireworks" as defined in this article may, however, be sold upon issuance of a license issued by the city. 
(Code 1978, § 7.86.01, subd. 1; Ord. No. 02-21, 7-22-2002) 
Secs. 26-228-26-247. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 26-248. - Application. 
    The application for a license shall contain the following information: name, address, and telephone number of applicant; the address of the location where legal fireworks will be sold; the type of legal fireworks to be sold, and the estimated quantity of legal fireworks that will be stored on the licensed premises. 
(Code 1978, § 7.86.01, subd. 3; Ord. No. 02-21, 7-22-2002) 
Sec. 26-249. - Processing application. 
    The application must be filed with the fire chief together with the permit fee. Following an inspection of the premises proposed to be licensed, the fire chief shall issue the permit if the conditions for license approval are satisfied and the location of the premises is properly zoned. If the fire chief denies the permit application, the permit applicant may, within ten days of the date of denial, appeal the fire chief's decision to the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 7.86.01, subd. 4; Ord. No. 02-21, 7-22-2002) 
Sec. 26-250. - Conditions for license issuance. 
    The license shall be issued subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The license is nontransferable, either to a different person or location. 
(2)  The license must be publicly displayed on the licensed premises. 
(3)  The licensed premises are subject to inspection by city employees including police officers during normal business hours. 
(4)  The sale and display of legal fireworks must be a permitted use in the zoning district in which the sales are to occur. All sales must be conducted from a permanent enclosed structure. 
(5)  The total inventory of legal fireworks stored on the premises may not exceed 200 pounds gross weight if the building is equipped with an automatic sprinkler system. If no system is present, a maximum of 50 pounds can be on site. 
(6)  The premises must be in compliance with the state building code and state fire code. 
(Code 1978, § 7.86.01, subd. 5; Ord. No. 02-21, 7-22-2002) 
Sec. 26-251. - License period and license fee. 
    Licenses shall be issued for a calendar year. The license fee is as established by ordinance. License fees shall not be prorated. A license shall be issued for each place of sale, including multiple locations within the premises. 
(Code 1978, § 7.86.01, subd. 6; Ord. No. 02-21, 7-22-2002) 
Sec. 26-252. - Revocation of license. 
    Following written notice and an opportunity for a hearing, the fire chief may revoke a license for violation of this article or state law concerning the sale, use or possession of fireworks. If a license is revoked, neither the applicant nor the licensed premises may obtain a license for 12 months from the date of the violation. If the fire chief revokes the license, the licensee may within ten days appeal the fire chief's decision to the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 7.86.01, subd. 7; Ord. No. 02-21, 7-22-2002) 
Secs. 26-253-26-282. - Reserved.

Secs. 26-283-26-301. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - GARBAGE AND REFUSE HAULERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-302. - Garbage defined. 
    The term "garbage" means the refuse animal and vegetable matter from the kitchens, pantries, dining rooms or other parts of hotels, restaurants, boardinghouses, tenement houses, dwelling houses, public institutions and market houses and private hospitals; the refuse animal matter from butcher shops; the refuse fruit and vegetables from stores and commission houses; the refuse animal and vegetable matter from grocery stores, fish stores and poultry stores; and all refuse accumulation containing animal or vegetable matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables and shall include such paper, sacks or other container used for garbage. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 2) 
Sec. 26-303. - Type of vehicle. 
    The licensed vehicle must be constructed and equipped so as to prevent fully any portion or part of the load from dropping off or leaking through the load carrying portion or box of such vehicle and from being blown or in any manner strewn from such vehicle into or upon any public roadway. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 7) 
State Law reference- Garbage trucks, Minn. Stats. §§ 169.64, 169.828, 169.86. 
Sec. 26-304. - Inspection. 
    All tanks, containers and vehicles used under said license shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall at all times be subject to inspection of any official of the city or other persons authorized to enforce this article. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 9) 
Sec. 26-305. - Records. 
    The city clerk shall keep a record of each license issued, the number thereof, the name of the licensee, the date issued, the expiration date, and the amount of the fee. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 10) 
Secs. 26-306-26-328. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 26-329. - Required. 
    No person, corporation, partnership, joint venture, association or other form of business venture shall engage in the business or occupation of collecting, removing and transporting of ashes, sweepings, rubbish or any other kind of refuse or garbage within the city, nor shall any person, corporation, partnership, association, joint venture or other form of business venture engaged in the business of collecting and removing ashes, sweepings, rubbish or any other kind of refuse or garbage outside the limits of the city transport the same over any public roadways of the city, without first obtaining a license to do so. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 1) 
Sec. 26-330. - Application and issuance. 
    The application for license shall be made to the city clerk and shall be subscribed and sworn to by the applicant and shall contain the name and address of the proposed licensee and of the owner of the vehicle to be used, and a description of the vehicle and of the tanks or containers in which the refuse is to be transported, and such other useful information as the city clerk may require. The city clerk may issue the license, except where expressly ordered not to do so by the council. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 3) 
Sec. 26-331. - Fee. 
    The fee for such license shall be as established by ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 4) 
Sec. 26-332. - Identification of vehicles. 
    At the time of issuance of the license, the city clerk shall issue a receipt of the license. This receipt shall be presented to any city official upon request or to any other person authorized to enforce this article. A separate receipt shall be issued for each vehicle. Each license shall display at all times in a prominent place on each vehicle licensed the name of the licensee. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 6) 
Sec. 26-333. - Insurance. 
    No license shall be issued and no renewal granted unless the person or business applying for such license shall file with the city clerk proof of the fact that any vehicle to be used by the licensee is insured against loss by an all-perils or general liability insurance policy issued by a company authorized to do business in the state in the minimum amount of $1,000,000.00. Such insurance policies must provide they will not be cancelled without ten days' prior written notice given to the city clerk. No cancellation of a policy of insurance at the request of the named insured, or the company, shall be effective until after the expiration of ten days' written notice to the city clerk. Cancellation of said insurance will cause an automatic suspension of the license granted hereunder. Such policy shall name the city as an additional insured. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 8) 
Sec. 26-334. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued hereunder may be revoked by the council as provided by the laws of the state, and any violation of this article shall constitute cause for revocation. 
(Code 1978, § 7.09, subd. 11) 
Secs. 26-335-26-356. - Reserved.

Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-11, § 2, adopted November 7, 2016, repealed article X §§ 26-357-26-366 and 26-385-26-389, which pertained to motor vehicle sales, repair and rental and derived from the Code of 1978, § 7.02, subds. 1-6 and 8-19 and Ord. No. 75-2, adopted March 24, 1975. 

Secs. 26-357-26-412. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MUSIC FESTIVALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-413. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Music festivals means and includes any gathering of individuals for the purpose of participating in or attending a musical carnival, rock festival, or like musical activity at which vocal or instrumental or both vocal and instrumental music is provided by professional or amateur performers, or by prerecorded means, and to which gatherings, members of the public are invited or admitted with or without the payment of admission charges in any form. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subd. 1; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-414. - Participants. 
    If the council shall, as a condition of issuance of the license, impose a limit on the number of persons to be admitted to the music festival and/or requiring that only holders of tickets shall be admitted to the premises on which the festival is to be held, it shall be unlawful for the licensee, or any agent or employee of the licensee: 
(1)  To allow, permit, or suffer the entrance to the premises in which the music festival is held of any person who does not possess a ticket, except a peace officer or other public officer in the performance of their duties; 
(2)  To sell, give, or distribute a greater number of tickets than the number authorized by the council; 
(3)  To allow, permit, or suffer the admission of any person to a music festival if such admission shall result in a greater number of persons present than authorized by the council. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subd. 12; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Secs. 26-415-26-441. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 26-442. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, group of persons, or entity to operate, conduct, maintain, advertise, sell or furnish tickets or other types of written authority to admission to a music festival in the city unless a license to operate or conduct such festival shall have been issued in the manner hereinafter described in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subd. 2; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-443. - Exemption; nontransferability. 
(a)  Exemption. Any person, group of persons, or entity seeking to hold, conduct, or operate a music festival, as that term is defined in section 26-413 on real property owned, leased, rented or possessed by any public entity, may be exempted from making application for a license, paying the application fee, providing the indemnity bond and the policy of public liability and property damage insurance required by section 26-444, provided each of the following conditions is satisfied: 
(1)  The person, group of persons, or entity seeking to hold, conduct, or operate a music festival makes application in writing to the council for a permit, on a form to be provided by the council, for the commencement of the festival; 
(2)  The applicant shall set forth the day, the time that shall not exceed four hours duration on any one day between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., and the place of the proposed festival, and the name, residence address, and telephone number of the applicant and each member of the performing musical groups, including their leaders; 
(3)  The applicant obtains and delivers to the council, at the time of making the application, a written sponsorship of or written permit for the festival signed by the public entity on whose real property the festival is proposed to be held, conducted or operated; 
(4)  The applicant confirms in the application, or in a separate writing attached thereto, that: 
a.  Each member of the musical groups, including their leaders, will receive no monetary compensation for performing in the festival; and 
b.  No charge whatsoever will be sought or collected for the admission to or attendance at the proposed festival; 
(5)  The applicant agrees in the application, or in a separate writing attached thereto, that he will assume full responsibility for restoring the immediate location of the festival, including the area occupied by the audience, to a clean and sanitary condition, and will remove and properly dispose of all debris, garbage, litter and other waste matter from, in and around said location, together with all advertising matter relating to the festival, within four hours immediately following the conclusion of the festival. 
(b)  The council shall examine the application and all supporting documents, including the written sponsorship or permit of the public entity, and if the council finds them to be in compliance with the required conditions set forth herein, the council shall issue a permit in writing to the applicant authorizing the music festival to be held, conducted or operated on the dates, and at the times and places indicated therein, and the council shall forthwith transmit a copy of the permit to the affected public entity. The council shall have the final decision making authority in connection with the issuance or denial of permits hereunder. 
(c)  No permit granted under the provisions of this section shall be transferable or removable to another location. The council shall have the right to revoke any permit issued under the provisions of this section after a hearing held upon at least eight hours' written notice given to the permittee for any of the causes set forth in section 26-447. The council may suspend operation and close any music festival prior to the expiration of the permit granted under the provisions of this section in the event of the occurrence of imminent threat of a riot, major disorder, or serious breach of the peace when, in its opinion, it becomes necessary to prevent injury to a person and/or damage to property. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subds. 13-15; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-444. - Application; agreement; indemnification. 
(a)  Application. Application for a license to conduct a music festival shall be made in writing to the city clerk at least 60 days prior to the time indicated for the commencement of the music festival. The application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the amount established by ordinance, which filing fee shall be paid to the city, and which said application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name (including alias), age, residence, mailing address, and telephone numbers of each person making the application; if the application is filed by a partnership, the name (including alias), age, residence, mailing address, and telephone numbers of each partner shall be included; if the applicant is a corporation or a common law or Massachusetts Trust, the application shall be signed by the president or secretary thereof, and in each instance shall contain their residences, mailing addresses, and telephone numbers, the telephone numbers, mailing addresses, and street addresses of the principal place of business of the corporation or trust and, in the case of the corporation, shall also include a certified copy of the articles of corporation and, in the case of a common law of Massachusetts Trust, shall include a certified copy of the trust indenture; 
(2)  The location and legal description of the premises where the music festival is proposed to be conducted, including all lands to be used for automobile parking and other incidental uses. The applicant shall submit proof of ownership of said premises and the written consent of all owners thereof for the proposed use; 
(3)  The date and the hours during which the festival is to be conducted; 
(4)  An estimate of the numbers of persons and spectators expected to attend the proposed music festival on each day it is conducted, together with detailed information supporting such estimate; 
(5)  A detailed statement of the applicant's program and plans to provide emergency communications, security protection, water supply, food supply, sanitary facilities, medical facilities and services, vehicle parking space, vehicle uses and on-site traffic control, sound and lighting equipment, fire protection, garbage, trash and litter clean-up service, and if it is proposed or expected that spectators or participants will remain at night or overnight, the arrangements for illuminating the premises and for camping and similar facilities. There shall be included a map showing the location of all such facilities and equipment on the premises, including the location of all loudspeakers and the location of all toilets, medical facilities and solid waste receptacles; 
(6)  A detailed explanation of the applicant's plan for policing the activity with particular emphasis on the control and prevention of alcoholic and drug consumption. 
(b)  Agreement. The application shall include an agreement filed by the applicants and by the owners of the subject premises that they will reimburse all owners and occupants of property adjoining the subject premises for any all and loss, injury or damages to such owners or occupants or to their property caused by the applicants, by the owner of the subject premises, or by any person attending or participating in the music festival, which damage shall not have occurred had the music festival not been held. Accompanying and securing said agreement shall be a surety company bond in favor of the city and all persons to whom the applicant and/or owners of the subject premises may be liable because of the agreement required by this subsection. Said bond shall be prepared by a corporate bonding company authorized to do business within the state and shall be in the amount of not less than $50,000.00. 
(c)  Indemnification. The application shall include an agreement filed by the applicants to defend, indemnify, save and hold the city harmless from and on account of any and all claims against the city for injury or damage of any kind or nature to persons or property in, upon or about the subject premises or arising from or in connection with said music festival from any cause whatsoever. The applicants shall covenant and agree to keep and maintain in full force and effect for a period of one year from and after the date upon which they shall have been issued a license to conduct a music festival, a policy of public liability and property damage insurance in standard form in insurance companies satisfactory to the city, and shall furnish the policy therefor to said city. Such public liability insurance shall be a general liability or all-perils policy and shall insure the city for limits of not less than $1,000,000.00. Said policy shall be delivered to the city at least ten days before the issuance of a license and such policy shall bear an endorsement of, or shall be accompanied by, evidence of receipt of payment of the premium thereon. The policy shall require that the city be notified 30 days in advance of cancellation of the policy. 
(d)  Cleanup. The application shall include an agreement signed by the applicants providing that within 72 hours after the conclusion of the music festival the applicants will clean up the premises, including contiguous public roads, ways and easements, and remove all debris, garbage, trash, litter and other waste matter from, in and around said premises, together with all advertising matter to said festival. 
(e)  Fingerprints. An application shall not be considered completed until each applicant has been fingerprinted and photographed by the city police department. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subds. 4-8; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-445. - Referral. 
    Upon receipt of the fully completed application, the city clerk shall give copies of the application to the council. The council shall determine whether, with regard to their specific areas of responsibility, the proposed music festival can be held without violation of any of the provisions of this Code. Within 45 days after the filing of a completed application, the council shall complete its investigations and shall notify the city clerk of their approval or disapproval of the issuance of a license. If the council approves the issuance of a license, the city clerk shall, after collecting the fee as established by ordinance, issue said license. If the council disapproves the issuance of a license, no license shall be issued, and the reasons for such disapproval, a copy of which shall be delivered to the applicant. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subd. 9; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-446. - Fee and expiration date. 
    The permit fee shall be as established by ordinance. The permit expiration date shall be as provided in article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subd. 3; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-447. - Suspension. 
    The council may suspend operation and close any music festival prior to the expiration of the license granted under the provisions of this Code in the event of the occurrence of a riot, major disorder, or serious breach of the peace when, in its opinion, it becomes necessary to prevent injury to a person and/or damage to property. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subd. 11; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Sec. 26-448. - Revocation. 
    The council shall have the right to revoke any license issued pursuant to this article after a public hearing held after written notice is given to the licensee at least 24 hours prior to such hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  The licensee fails, neglects or refuses to fulfill any of the conditions imposed upon the granting of a license; 
(2)  The licensee fails, refuses or neglects to fulfill any of the provisions of the proposed program or plans; 
(3)  The licensee permits the music festival to be conducted in a disorderly manner or allows any person to remain on the premises while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or any narcotics or dangerous drug; 
(4)  The licensee violates, or attempts to violate, any law of the state and/or provisions of this article or any other provisions of this Code; 
(5)  The licensee has previously made a false, misleading or fraudulent statement of material fact in the application for a license or in any other document required pursuant to this article. Written notice of such revocation shall be forwarded by the city clerk to the licensee at the address given in the application. Such revocation shall become effective immediately after ordered by the council. 
(Code 1978, § 7.07, subd. 10; Ord. No. 75-2, 3-24-1975) 
Secs. 26-449-26-479. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PAWNBROKERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, Minn. Stats. ch. 325J; local regulation of pawnbrokers, Minn. Stats. §§ 325J.02, 325J.13. 

Sec. 26-480. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Billable transaction means every reportable transaction conducted by a pawnbroker, regardless of the number of items received in that transaction. 
    Licensed premises means the specific building which has been licensed pursuant to this article. The term "licensed premises" does not include any outbuildings attached to or detached from the licensed premises. 
    Pawnbroker means a person who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal property or other valuable thing; who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable thing on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated price; or who loans money secured by chattel mortgage or by personal property, taking possession of the property or any part thereof so mortgaged. To the extent that a pawnbroker business includes buying personal property previously used, rented, or leased, the provisions of this section shall be applicable. Any bank, savings and loan association, or credit union shall not be deemed a pawnbroker for purposes of this section. 
    Receive means to purchase, accept for sale on consignment or take in pawn any secondhand goods. 
    Reportable transaction means every transaction conducted by a pawnbroker, inside the city, in which merchandise defined in section 26-493 is received through a pawn purchase, sale, consignment or trade, or in which a pawn is renewed, extended, redeemed or voided, is a reportable transaction, and for which a daily report to the police department is required. 
    Unique identifier means a serial number, identification number, model number, owner applied identifier or engraving, "Operation ID" number or symbol, or other unique marking. 
(Ord. No. 09-08, § 1(7.13.01), 5-12-2009) 
Sec. 26-481. - General. 
(a)  Purpose. The council finds that pawnbrokers potentially provide an opportunity for the commission of crimes and their concealment because such businesses have the ability to receive and transfer stolen property easily and quickly. The council also finds that consumer protection regulation is warranted in transactions involving pawnbrokers. The purpose of this article is therefore to prevent pawn broking from being used as facilities for commission of crimes and to assure that such businesses comply with basic consumer protection standards, thereby protecting the public health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(b)  Provisions of state law adopted. The provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 325J and as amended from time to time are hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth at this point. 
(c)  License required. 
(1)  No person, partnership, or corporation shall engage in or carry on the business of a Pawnbroker, without a license issued by the city, for each and every separate office or place of business operated by such licensee in the city. The annual fee for such license shall be set by council resolution. 
(2)  A license under this section shall authorize the licensee to carry on its business only at the permanent place of business designated in the license. No license may be transferred to a different location or a different licensee. 
(d)  APS established. To help the police department better regulate current and future pawn businesses, decrease and stabilize costs associated with the regulation of the pawn industry, and increase identification of criminal activities in the pawn industry through the timely collection and sharing of pawn transaction information, this section also implements and establishes the use of the automated pawn system (APS). 
(e)  License limitation. No more than three pawnbroker licensed businesses shall be permitted by the city at any one time. Priority shall be given to qualified applicants for renewal of existing licenses. 
(f)  License fee. 
(1)  The annual license fees for licenses issued under this section shall be set by council resolution and listed in the rates and fees.
