State Law reference- Municipal utilities, Minn. Stats. §§ 410.33, 412.321 et seq.; utilities authorized, Minn. Stats. § 444.075. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 58-1-58-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATES AND CHARGES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Water and charges, Minn. Stats. § 444.075. 

Sec. 58-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Utility or system means any or all of the following: 
(1)  The city's water system; 
(2)  The city's sewage collection and treatment system; 
(3)  The city's street lighting system; 
(4)  The city's storm sewer system. 
Sec. 58-20. - Rates and charges. 
    Rates and charges for service rendered by the system shall be set by council ordinance. However, the rates fixed shall not be in excess of an amount reasonably calculated to defray the cost of the proper maintenance and operation of the system, including the recovery of the initial capital costs and the cost of amortization of any indebtedness incurred by the issuance of indebtedness for the improvement of the system. 
(Code 1978, §§ 4.40.09, 4.41.03, 4.80.04; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 94-06; Ord. No. 00-10, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 58-21. - Service charges. 
(a)  There shall be service charges for turning water on or off at the request of the property owner and for raising or lowering stop box tops to correspond with ground level change made by the property owner. 
(b)  When the customer or property owner wants to terminate the water service serving the property owner's property, the property owner shall notify the city to turn off the water service. The meter shall be read at that time to determine the final bill and the property will be charged a disconnection fee as set by council ordinance. 
(c)  In all cases where water has been turned off for the nonpayment of bills or for violation of any rules or regulations of the city, such water shall not be again turned on unless and until such bills have been fully paid plus interest and penalty, and all delinquent charges removed and a charge for turning such water on has been paid. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.09; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-22. - Liability of property owner. 
    The property receiving the service shall be liable to the city for all bills accruing through the use of water and sewer facilities upon the owner's premises whether the same be personally used by the owner, the owner's tenant or other occupant of the premises. 
(Code 1978, §§ 4.40.09, subd. 1, 4.41.03, subd. 1, 4.80.04, subd. 1; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 94-06; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000; Ord. No. 00-10, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 58-23. - Billing statements. 
(a)  Billing statements for water and sewer charges for the preceding period shall be mailed to each customer within 15 business days of period end, and shall include the amount due for repairs on meters, fines, penalties or other indebtedness and such statement shall be deemed sufficient notice to the customer of charges made 
(b)  Billing statements for street lighting charges for the preceding period shall be mailed to each customer and shall be deemed sufficient notice to the customer of charges made. Said statements shall be due and payable by the date indicated on the specific billing statement. 
(Code 1978, §§ 4.40.09, subd. 2, 4.41.03, subd. 2; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 94-06) 
Sec. 58-24. - Delinquent statements. 
(a)  All billing statements not paid on or before the due date shall be considered delinquent. It shall be the duty of the city to promptly collect delinquent accounts, and the city shall notify each delinquent customer or, in case the customer cannot be found, then the person in charge of the premises, of the amount of the bill due. All billings 60 days past due as of September 1 of the calendar year will be considered delinquent with possible certification of delinquent amount added to the following year taxes payable if delinquent amount is not received by November 1 of such calendar year. All delinquent customers will be notified by the city as to delinquency amount. 
(b)  All amounts due utility service plus interest and penalty may be collected in a legal action brought for that purpose in the name of the city; or the city administrator may certify to the county auditor the amount due for street lighting charges plus interest and penalty, together with the legal description of the premises served and the county auditor shall thereupon enter such amount within the tax levy on the premises collectible with the taxes for the ensuing year. 
(Code 1978, §§ 4.40.09, subd. 4, 4.41.03, subd. 4, 4.80.04, subd. 3; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 94-06; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000; Ord. No. 00-10, 9-5-2000) 
State Law reference- Authority to collect unpaid charges as special assessments, Minn. Stats. § 429.101. 
Secs. 58-25-58-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER AND SEWER SYSTEMS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building sewer means that portion of the sewerage system located between the property line and the structure served. 
    Customer means any individual, firm or company who shall receive city water and/or sanitary sewer service. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Municipal water system or city water means the municipal water system of the city. 
    Public sewer or municipal sewer means the municipal sewer system of the city. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer that carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Sewer lateral means that portion of the sewerage system located between the property line and the sewer main. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.03; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-51. - Systems deemed public utilities; water and sewer utility fund. 
    Any municipal water system and/or sanitary sewer system that is constructed in the city pursuant to the regulations of this Code shall be operated as public utilities, and all revenues and operating expenditures of said utilities shall be properly accounted for in a separate municipal fund that shall be a combined water and sewer utility fund. The council shall have authority to establish fees for connection to and use of the municipal water and sanitary sewer systems from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.02; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-52. - Tampering with systems prohibited. 
    No person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the city sanitary sewer system or the city water system. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.04; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-53. - Access to premises. 
    The city inspector, so designated, and other duly authorized employees of the city, bearing proper identification, shall at reasonable times be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in connection with the operation of the city sanitary sewer system or the city water system. Such employees shall also be permitted to enter for inspection, meter reading and examining fixtures causing unnecessary waste of water to the detriment of the system. Said employee shall promptly notify the owner or occupant of such premises in writing of required repairs, if any, and, in the event any required repairs are not made within ten days, the city may shut off the water. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.05; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-54. - Fees and permits. 
(a)  The issuance of permits and licenses, the collection of fees and the requirements for bonds and insurance shall be as set by ordinance. 
(b)  No person shall commence any plumbing work of any kind where a permit is necessary without first obtaining a proper permit from the city and complying with all the terms thereof. 
(c)  An excavation permit is required if any part of the excavation for municipal water or sanitary sewer service is within a city street or right-of-way. Such excavation permits shall be issued in accordance with the provisions of this Code regulating excavations in streets. 
(d)  The charges for tapping water mains, and the amount of the water meter usage fee and all other fees, shall be paid at the time application for service is made and before the service is installed. Water service will not be turned on until all charges against the premises are paid. 
(e)  Installation fees for remote meter readers and meter shall be as set by council ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.08; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-55. - Variances. 
    The council may permit variances from the strict application of any of the provisions of this Code if it is satisfied that there are special circumstances or conditions affecting the premises for which the variance is requested and that the granting of such variance will not materially adversely affect the health, safety or general welfare or public or private property. Any variation permitted under this provision must be noted on the permit. A public hearing is not required. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.10; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Secs. 58-56-58-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MANDATORY CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 58-86. - Definitions. 
(a)  As used in section 58-87, urban services (sewer and/or water) are "available" to a residential improved property when said services are located in a street or public easement that is adjacent to or abuts the residential improved property. 
(b)  The term "non-functional private sewer system" means an individual on-site sewer system that does not comply with Minn. Rules ch. 7080, which chapter is entitled "Minnesota Pollution Control Agency, Water Quality Division, Individual Sewage Treatment Systems." 
(c)  The term "non-functional private water system" means an individual on-site water system which does not comply with Minn. Rules ch. 4725, which chapter is entitled "Department of Health Wells and Borings" and/or rules and regulations of the state plumbing code. 
(d)  As used in section 8.6.3 of the city Charter, the term "original assessment" shall mean that the initial assessment amount that would have been assessed and levied against a property for a local improvement project that first extended urban services (sewer and/or water) to said property. 
(e)  As used in section 8.6.3 of the city Charter, an assessment which is "consistent with the original assessment" is that amount which would be assessed and levied against a property for a local improvement project which extended urban services (sewer and/or water) to said property as if said urban services were installed at the time the property connects to the city's sewer and/or water utilities, or is levied a special assessment for said benefit. 
(Code 1978, § 4.70.03; Ord. No. 97-04) 
Sec. 58-87. - Purpose and applicability. 
    The purpose of this division is to provide uniform regulations to carry out and make effective section 8.6 of the city Charter. This division applies to any residential improved property in the city, which property has urban services (sewer and/or water) available to it and which property has not been assessed for the benefit of said urban services. 
(Code 1978, § 4.70.02; Ord. No. 97-04) 
Sec. 58-88. - Repair of systems. 
(a)  Upon determination that either a private sewer system or a private water system or both is a non-functional system as defined herein, the city's building official shall certify either or both of said systems as "non-functional." 
(b)  An existing home which is serviced by a non-functional private sewer and/or private water system shall be required to either: 
(1)  Connect to the city's sewer system if the home's sewer system is non-functional or connect to the city's water system if the home's water system is non-functional. The connection date shall be within six months of the date on which the system was declared non-functional; or 
(2)  Cause the non-functional system to be functional by compliance with either Minn. Rules ch. 4725, or Minn. Rules ch. 7080, as applicable. 
(Code 1978, § 4.70.04; Ord. No. 97-04; Ord. No. 05-08, 5-16-2005) 
Sec. 58-89. - Notice to public. 
    The city shall cause its public property records to reflect that any property not assessed because the property owner elected to remain on a functional private sewer and/or private water system is subject to a pending sewer and/or water system assessment or connection charge when said property connects to either the city's sewer or water system. 
(Code 1978, § 4.70.05; Ord. No. 97-04) 
Sec. 58-90. - Election to remain on functional private system. 
    The procedure by which a property owner may elect to remain on a functional private sewer and/or water system shall be as follows: Upon receipt by the property owner of mailed notice advising that a public hearing is to be held relating to the assessment of costs of public improvement project which project includes extending urban services (sewer and/or water) to a home owned by the property owner, the property owner who elects to remain on a functional private sewer and/or private water system shall: 
(1)  Certify to the city, on a recordable form provided by the city, that the property owner's existing home is serviced by a functional private sewer and/or private water system. 
(2)  The written certification referenced in subsection (1) of this section shall be filed with the city administrator prior to the assessment hearing or presented to the presiding officer at the hearing. 
(Code 1978, § 4.70.06; Ord. No. 97-04) 
Secs. 58-91-58-108. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WATER SYSTEM 

Sec. 58-109. - Operation, records and inspection. 
(a)  The city shall keep a record of the exact location and size of all parts of the municipal water systems, connections thereto, and other measurements or records which may be necessary. 
(b)  The city shall superintend all connections for service, and examine all service pipes to ensure that they are properly laid, and that all meters are properly installed and operating. The city also shall have charge of inspecting the premises entered by service pipes, examining the condition of all water fixtures, and shall warn against all abuses of the municipal water systems including potential cross connections. 
(c)  No person, other than an employee of the city, shall operate the curb-stop (shut-off valve). 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 1; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-110. - Applications for service. 
(a)  Any customer desiring to connect a dwelling, building, or other structure to the municipal water system shall apply therefor on a form provided by the city. Said form shall call for such information as the council may from time to time require. 
(b)  The owner shall connect to the municipal water system at the time of sewer connection. 
(c)  Each applicant by such application shall agree to be bound by all provisions of this Code, amendments thereto and all rules and regulations established by the city relating to the municipal water system. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 2; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 10-07, § 2, 4-13-2010) 
Sec. 58-111. - Permits for taps, special assessments. 
    No permit shall be issued to tap or connect with any water facility of the city either directly or indirectly from any lot or tract of land unless the city administrator shall have certified: 
(1)  That such lot or tract of land to be served by such tap or connection has been individually assessed for its proportionate share of the cost of construction of the facilities to which such connection is made; 
(2)  If no assessment has been levied for such construction cost, that proceedings for levying such assessment have been or will be commenced in due course; 
(3)  That no assessment has been levied but a connection fee equal to the portion of the cost of constructing said facility which would be assessable against said lot or tract of land has been paid to the city; or 
(4)  That since the time of the original assessment proceedings the lot or tract of land originally assessed has been further subdivided or developed at a higher density and that a sum equal to the cost of constructing such facility, in comparison with other premises, which would have been assessable against such lot or tract, has been paid to the city. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 3; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-112. - Water meters. 
(a)  The city shall exclusively own, control and supply the water meters to be used in the municipal water system. The meter may be removed or replaced or changed as to size and type whenever deemed necessary. The meter shall be removed and re-tested on a periodic basis by the city for the purpose of certifying accuracy. There shall be no charge for this periodic testing. 
(b)  No person shall be allowed municipal water until the city determines that the meter supplied has been placed in such manner that it will register all water consumed, and that all other parts of the plumbing and pipe fitting in and about the premises has been in full compliance with the rules and regulations which the city shall make from time to time. 
(c)  Licensed master plumbers shall install or supervise the installation of meter horns. The meter horns shall be given to the licensed master plumber or plumber's agent upon securing the plumbing permit. 
(d)  The city shall install all water meters. No customer shall be provided with water unless such meter has been installed. Remote readers shall be installed with each meter by the city at a location designated by the city. 
(e)  The customer is prohibited from obstructing the meter so as to interfere with the reading or repairing of the water meter or remote reader. 
(f)  The city shall ensure that every customer is provided with a minimum five-eighths-inch water meter. An appropriate charge, reflective of the size of meter, will be required for the use of the meter. This charge shall be established by council resolution. 
(g)  Every water meter shall be sealed by the city at the time of installation or repair. No person shall break or remove said seal. Any broken seal or removed water meter shall be reported to the city within 24 hours of such action. 
(h)  If any meters are damaged by freezing, hot water, etc., either by carelessness or neglect of the customer, said customer must pay for the repair of such meters. The cost of ordinary maintenance and repairs of all meters owned by the city shall be borne by the city. 
(i)  At the written request of any customer, the city will test, or cause to be tested, the meter supplying the premises of the customer. If desired, the customer may be present at the time any such test is made. The result of any such test shall be reported to the customer in every case and if the meter registers in excess of ten percent error, this test will be performed at no charge. 
(j)  If the testing of a meter, as hereinabove provided, indicates that it registers in excess of ten percent error, the charge to the customer for water used during the quarter and previous quarter within which such test is made shall be equitably adjusted by the city on the basis of the meter test results. Any other adjustment of charges for water supplied through meters shall be made only by the council. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 4; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-113. - Water connections. 
(a)  The minimum size water service from the curb stop to the dwelling can be one-inch high density poly ethylene (HDPE) or one-inch copper. The HDPE pipe shall contain a 12-gauge tracer wire from curb stop to meter horn and must be accessible at both ends. The minimum size water service from the watermain to the curb stop shall be one-inch copper. 
(b)  The corporation cock inserted in the distributing pipe must be of the size specified on the permit order. Every copper service pipe must be laid sufficiently waving to allow not less than one foot of extra length in such manner as to prevent rupture by settlement. The service pipe must be placed sufficiently below the surface in all cases, so protected or arranged as to prevent rupture from freezing. All services shall be inspected by the city prior to being backfilled. 
(c)  No person shall make any attachment to any pipe or water fixture in premises from which water has been shut off, or make any connection with any service pipe which is not in use between the water mains and the meters, without the party desiring such work to be done having first made application to and obtaining a written permit from the city for the performance of such work, and no person shall make any replacement tap or connect any tap or connection theretofore made in any water main without first removing the old service and plugging the water main. When a new building is erected on the site of an old one, and it is desired to increase or change the old water service, no connection with the mains shall be permitted until all the old service has been removed and the main plugged. 
(d)  The service pipe must extend from the main to the inside of the building, or, if not taken into a building, then to the hydrant or other fixtures which it is intended to supply. A stop cock accessible from the surface through a sleeve, without digging in all cases, must be placed outside in a box at the property line. All stop boxes and cocks must be approved by the city. All stop boxes at the property line must be set in front of the building intended to be supplied or as approved by the city. The stop cock, together with box and cover, are the property of the city and all unauthorized persons are forbidden to interfere with them. 
(e)  The service pipe from the city water main to the meter shall enter the building so that the meter horn is in a horizontal position. In no case should there be more than 12 inches of pipe exposed between the point of the entrance through the basement floor and the stop. 
(f)  The water pipe connecting with the municipal water main shall have no joints therein when located under the basement or slab floor. 
(g)  If, for any cause, a person laying the service pipe should fail to have the corporation cock inserted or the connection made to the curb stop at the time specified in the application, a written notice to that effect must be left with the city fixing another day on which said connection will be made. A notice must be given at least two days previous to the excavation for the laying of a service pipe and the connection made before 4:00 p.m., except in a special case and then the work shall be done only on written order from the city. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 5; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 13-18, § 2, 10-22-2013) 
Sec. 58-114. - Water service, freezing. 
    The water service to a building shall not be turned on in freezing weather unless the temperature within said building is 50 degrees Fahrenheit or above. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 6; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-115. - Breaks, interrupted service. 
    No claim shall be made against the city for interruption of service caused by the breaking of any water main or service pipe or fixture. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 7; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-116. - Water connections prohibited. 
(a)  No more than one house or building, or in the case of townhouses, one unit, shall be supplied from one water service pipe except by special permission of the city. Whenever two or more parties are supplied from one pipe connecting with the distribution main, each building or part of the building must have a separate stop box at the curb. 
(b)  No water pipe of the municipal water system shall be connected with any pump, well pipe or tank that is connected with any source other than the city water system. When such are found, the city shall notify the customer to disconnect same, and if not done immediately, the city water supply shall be turned off. 
(c)  Any customer of the city that desires to use the resident's own well system in conjunction with use of city water, that well system must be completely disconnected from the city water and sewer utilities. Said well system shall only supply spigots located on the outside of the residence or building or to yard hydrants. Water obtained from those spigots shall only be used for watering lawns, gardens or shrubs, washing cars and other such uses and only in such a manner that none of the drainage from such use goes into the city sewer system. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 8; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-117. - Maintenance. 
    The service pipe to the stop box (curb stop) and the connection thereto shall be the property of the customer and must be protected and maintained by the customer. In the event such customer shall fail to make necessary repairs to such service connection or pipe within 24 hours after being notified by the city to do so, the city shall make such repairs and the cost thereof shall be charged to the customer and shall be collected in the same manner as other bills for water consumption are collected. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 9; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-118. - Sprinkling; limitation municipal water system. 
(a)  In the case of fire or other emergencies that may be declared by the city administrator in any area served by the municipal water system, all lawn hoses must be shut off and all unnecessary use of water must be stopped. 
(b)  Customers shall maintain taps, faucets valves and other water facilities so that water waste is eliminated. Irrigation systems shall be adjusted to avoid sprinkling of city streets and driveways. 
(c)  Odd-even sprinkling. A ban on sprinkling shall be in effect between Memorial Day and Labor Day. Residents may water on odd-numbered days if their address ends in an odd number, and on even-numbered days if their address ends in an even number. 
(d)  During the period from Memorial Day through Labor Day, no watering shall be permitted between 10:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. since a significant amount of water is lost due to evaporation during the hot portions of the day. 
(e)  Exemptions. Newly sodded or seeded yards will be exempt from the odd-even restriction for a period of two weeks. Overseeding or spot repair of existing established yards may be watered every day with a hand controlled hose. No watering will be allowed between 12:00 noon and 6:00 p.m. for these exemptions. Other exemptions not subject to the afternoon restriction include car washing, filling of children's swimming pools, and children playing in hose operated sprinklers or water toys. 
(f)  Sanctions for violations of this section shall be as follows. All fees shall be added to and become a part of the water bill for the premises serviced. 
(1)  First violation: a written notice shall be given by registered mail. 
(2)  Second violation: a fee as established by ordinance shall be imposed. 
(3)  Third violation: a fee as established by ordinance shall be imposed. 
(4)  Fourth violation: water service shall be turned off. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 10; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 04-24, 7-12-2004) 
Sec. 58-119. - Opening hydrants. 
    No person, except authorized city employees or a member of the fire department in case of fire, shall open any fire hydrant in the water system for any purpose whatsoever, without first securing authorization from the city. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.06, subd. 11; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 04-24, 7-12-2004) 
Sec. 58-120. - Disconnecting city water service. 
(a)  Any city water service customer or property owner responsible for paying for water service desiring to discontinue the use of city water must make a written request to disconnect the service to the director of public works. The director of public works will have the service at the curb stop box shut off by authorized personnel. 
(b)  No unauthorized person will shut off the water service. 
(c)  A fee to be determined from time to time by ordinance of the city council shall be charged for disconnecting service. Such fee will include charges for restoring service. 
(d)  The building official or the director of public works to protect the public health and safety and in order to protect the public water supply and/or private property, may order the city water service immediately disconnected to any property upon determining that any of the following conditions exits: 
(1)  The property is vacant; 
(2)  The property is unsecured; 
(3)  The property is determined to be uninhabitable or unsuitable for occupancy; 
(4)  Other utilities to the property providing heat and/or light have been shut off; 
(5)  The property has plumbing that is failing or unsafe; 
(6)  That running water to the property creates an unsanitary or unsafe condition to anyone who may enter the property; or 
(7)  The property owner or occupant has refused access by authorized officials as authorized by this division. 
(e)  The water service shall not be re-connected to the property until it has passed an inspection by the chief building official and, the necessary permits have been issued and fees have been paid. The inspection fee will be determined from time to time by ordinance of the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.12; Ord. No. 08-31, § 1(4.40.12), 11-25-2008) 
Secs. 58-121-58-138. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SEWER SYSTEM 

Sec. 58-139. - Operation, records and inspection. 
(a)  The city shall keep a record of the location and size of all parts of the municipal sewer systems, connections thereto, and other measurements or records which may be necessary. 
(b)  The city shall superintend all connections for service, inspect all service pipes and the premises to ensure that the installation conforms to the intent of the plumbing code. 
(c)  No sanitary sewer service line between the sanitary sewer main and the plumbing system of any dwelling, building or other structure to be served shall be installed until a connection permit has been obtained from the city and the appropriate fees set by the council from time to time are paid. In installing said sanitary sewer service line, the applicant shall adhere to standards regarding location, size, grade, materials and workmanship as required by the plumbing code. After the sanitary sewer service connection has been accomplished, the applicant shall notify the city. It shall be unlawful to cover the sanitary sewer service line until an inspection has been completed to ensure that a proper and suitable connection has been made. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.07, subd. 1; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-140. - Application for service. 
(a)  No buildings located on property lying outside the limits of the city shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system without first having a resolution by the city or township in whose jurisdiction the property lies stating that said city or township has no objection to such connection. 
(b)  The city shall make every effort to design the sewage collection system to accommodate gravity flow to the system from adjacent properties. However, in instances it may be technically or economically infeasible to provide gravity service to every structure. In such cases, the property owner shall furnish and install a means of lifting the sewage for discharge into the sanitary sewer. Such system shall be reviewed and accepted by the city. The cost of installation, operation and maintenance of such system shall be the responsibility of the property owner. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.07, subd. 2; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-141. - Required use of sewers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge into any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or other polluted waters. 
(c)  No person shall deposit the contents taken from any vault, privy, cesspool, septic tank or private drain into any sanitary sewer of the city unless a permit is obtained from the city. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.07, subd. 3; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 10-07, § 2, 4-13-2010) 
Sec. 58-142. - Discharge of prohibited substances. 
    No person shall discharge or permit to be discharged, directly or indirectly, into the sanitary sewer system of the city, rain water from roofs, yards, lawns, streets, or alleys; groundwater; water or other fluid used for the operation of air cooling and air conditioning equipment in plants or units, any gasoline, naphtha, benzene, kerosene, turpentine or any spirit gas or fluid, or any materials of an explosive or suffocating nature, or that may possibly create combustible or suffocating gases or vapors; waters having a PH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.5 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage to wastewater facilities; nor discharge or permit to be discharged directly or indirectly into said sanitary sewer system any gravel, sand, dirt or any other heavy materials or any substances. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.07, subd. 4; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Sec. 58-143. - Maintenance. 
(a)  The cost of installing the sanitary sewer service line between the building and main service stub shall be borne wholly by the customer. After the initial connection to the main service stub, the customer shall thereafter be liable for all maintenance and repairs to the sanitary sewer service line between the street main and the building being served. 
(b)  There shall be no discharge of any substance or matter that may form a deposit or obstruction in the public sanitary sewer. Any customer discharging such a substance shall, within five days of written notice, provide said drain with an approved means to prevent any substance or matter from passing into the drain or sanitary sewer that may cause a deposit or obstruction therein. In case of neglect or refusal to provide a cesspool or catchbasin, or to clean out or repair or alter such drain, for a period of five days, the council shall cause the same to be repaired, altered, cleaned and provided with such other means to prevent any substances or matter from passing into the sanitary sewer or drain that may cause a deposit or obstruction therein as it may deem expedient, at the expense of the customer. 
(Code 1978, § 4.40.07, subd. 5; Ord. No. 92-05, 6-29-1992) 
Secs. 58-144-58-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STREET LIGHTING UTILITY 

Sec. 58-170. - Operation as public utility; separate municipal fund; fees. 
    All municipal street lighting systems constructed in the city shall be operated as a public utility and all revenues and expenditures of said utility shall be properly accounted for in a separate municipal fund. The council shall have authority to establish fees for the use of the system from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 4.41.02; Ord. No. 94-06) 
Secs. 58-171-58-193. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STORM DRAINAGE UTILITY 

Sec. 58-194. - Storm sewer system; statutory authority. 
    The provisions of Minn. Stats. § 444.075, authorizes cities to impose just and reasonable charges for the use and availability of storm sewer facilities ("charges"). By this article, the city elects to exercise such authority. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.01; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000) 
Sec. 58-195. - Findings and determinations. 
    In providing for such charges, the findings and determination set out in this article are made. 
(1)  In the exercise of its governmental authority and in order to promote the public health, safety, convenience and general welfare, the city has constructed, operated and maintained a storm sewer system ("the system"). This article is adopted in the further exercise of such authority and for the same purposes. 
(2)  The system, as constructed, heretofore has been financed and paid for through the imposition of special assessments and ad valorem taxes. Such financing methods were appropriate to the circumstances at the time they were used. It is now necessary and desirable to provide an alternative method of recovering some or all of the further costs of improving, maintaining and operating the system through the imposition of charges as provided in this article. 
(3)  In imposing charges, it is necessary to establish a methodology that undertakes to make them just and equitable. Taking into account the status of completion of the system, past methods of recovering system costs, the topography of the city and other relevant factors, it is determined that it would be just and equitable to assign responsibility for some or all of the future costs of operating, maintaining and improving the system on the basis of the expected stormwater runoff from the various parcels of land within the city during a standard five-year rainfall event. 
(4)  Assigning costs and making charges based upon expected typical stormwater runoff cannot be done with mathematical precision but can only be accomplished within reasonable and practical limits. The provisions of this article undertake to establish a reasonable and practical methodology for making such charges. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.02; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000; Ord. No. 00-10, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 58-196. - Rates and charges. 
(a)  Residential equivalent factor. Rates and charge for the use and availability of the system shall be determined through the use of a residential equivalent factor (REF). For the purposes of this article, one REF is defined as the ratio of the average volume of surface water runoff coming from one acre of land and subjected to a particular use, to the average volume of runoff coming from one acre of land subjected to typical single-family residential use within the city during a standard five-year rainfall event. 
(b)  Residential equivalent unit. Rates and charges for the use and availability of the system shall be determined through the use of a residential equivalent unit (REU). For the purposes of this article, one REU is defined as the product of the acreage of a particular parcel multiplied by the REF. 
(c)  Determination of REFs and REUs. The REF shall be based on the relative runoff generated by any land use compared to the expected runoff from a typical half-acre single-family dwelling. This relationship shall be interpreted as a function of the percent of the total lot area that is impervious and shall be applied as determined in the table below.

For the purpose of this article, the term "impervious" shall mean any ground surface that is not substantially covered with vegetation and produces run-off amounts that are in excess of undeveloped land. Paths and parking areas that consist of gravel and dirt will be considered impervious surface. 
(d)  Appeals. Appeals from the city administrator's determination of the proper classifications may be made to the city council. The council may adjust, by ordinance, the storm drainage fee for a parcel or a class of parcels based upon hydrologic data to be supplied by property owners, which data demonstrates a hydrologic response substantially different from the standards. Such adjustments of stormwater drainage fees shall not be made retroactively. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.03; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000; Ord. No. 00-10, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 58-197. - Establishing basic rate. 
    In determining charges, the council shall, from time to time, by ordinance, establish a basic system rate to be charged against one acre of land having an REF of one. The charge to be made against each parcel of land shall then be determined by multiplying the REU times the basic system rate. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.04, subd. 1; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000; Ord. No. 00-10, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 58-198. - Standardized acreage. 
    For the purpose of simplifying and equalizing charges against property used for residential purposes, the following process shall be used. Single-family, two-family, townhouse units and farmland properties that contain only a farmstead and typical associated outbuildings shall be considered as a single-family residential property. Single-family residential properties shall be considered to have an acreage of one-fourth acre and an REF of 1. Single-family properties with a business on the site shall be charged one-half the residential rate and one-half the business rate until such time as the business is no longer active on the site, at which time the rate shall be the standard single-family residential rate. The property owner shall be responsible for notifying the city of this change of status. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.05; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000; Ord. No. 00-10, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 04-14, 6-1-2004) 
Sec. 58-199. - Adjustments of charges. 
    The city council may, by resolution, from time to time, adopt policies providing for the adjustment of charges for parcels or groups of parcels, based upon hydrologic data supplied by affected property owners, demonstrating an actual hydrologic response substantially different from the REF being used for the parcel. Such adjustment shall be made only after receiving the recommendation of the city administrator and shall not be made effective retroactively. If the adjustment would have the effect of changing the REF for all or substantially all of the land uses in a particular classification; however, such adjustment shall be accomplished by amending the REF table in section 58-196. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.06; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000) 
Sec. 58-200. - Excluded lands. 
    No charge for system availability or service shall be made against land which is either public street right-of-way or vacant and unimproved with substantially all of its surface having vegetation as ground cover. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.07; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000) 
Sec. 58-201. - Supplying information. 
    The owner, occupant or person in charge of any premises shall supply the city with such information as the city may reasonably request related to the use, development and area of the premises. Willful failure to provide such information or to falsify it is a violation of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.08; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000) 
Sec. 58-202. - Estimated charges. 
    If the owner, occupant or person in charge of any premises fails or refuses to provide the information requested, as provided in section 58-201, the charge for such premises shall be estimated and billed in accordance with such estimate, based upon information available to the city. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.09; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000) 
Sec. 58-203. - Drainage and erosion control. 
(a)  Drainage plan. In the development improvement or alteration of land, the direction, quantity or quality of drainage shall not be changed unless plans for the development are submitted to the city engineer and are found to be in compliance with the city's comprehensive surface water management plan or have received a variance from the appropriate water management organization as necessary. Runoff shall be properly channeled into a storm drain, watercourse, ponding area or other public facility. 
(b)  Erosion and sediment control plan. Prior to the issuance of a building or grading permit for any development, improvement or alteration of land, a plan for erosion and sedimentation control shall be presented with the site plan. The erosion and sedimentation control plan shall specify the measures to be used before, during and after construction until the soil and slope are stabilized by permanent cover. These control measures shall be maintained in good working order until site stabilization occurs. 
(c)  Plan approval. In areas which are susceptible to erosion hazard or sedimentation damage, the city may require the erosion and sedimentation control plan to be approved by the appropriate water management organization prior to the issuance of a permit. 
(d)  Approval. Plans and provisions required for compliance with this article must be submitted to the community development director for approval. 
(Code 1978, § 4.80.10; Ord. No. 00-01, 3-13-2000) 
Chapter 62 - WATERWAYS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
