(b)  Pipes or steel rods shall be placed at each lot corner. All United States, state, county or other official benchmarks, monuments or triangular stations in or adjacent to the property shall be preserved in precise position and shall be recorded on the plat. All lot and block dimensions shall be on the plat and all necessary angles pertaining to the lots and blocks as an aid to future surveys shall be shown on the plat. No ditto marks will be permitted in indicating dimensions. 
(c)  To ensure that all irons and monuments are correctly in place following the final grading of a plat, a second monumentation shall be required. Proof of the second monumentation shall be in the form of a surveyor's certificate and this requirement shall additionally be a condition of certificate of occupancy as provided for in this chapter, as may be amended. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.51; Ord. No. 75-05, 6-22-1975; Ord. No. 03-39, 9-29-2003) 
Sec. 117-617. - Vehicle access into construction sites. 
    There will not be any building construction allowed until a Class 5 driving surface is installed to within at least 300 feet of any building. Additionally, there will not be any certificate of occupancy allowed until the parking or driving surface is paved with at least one layer of bituminous surfacing. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.52; Ord. No. 75-05, 6-22-1975; Ord. No. 79-06, 7-29-1979; Ord. No. 03-39, 9-29-2003) 
Sec. 117-618. - Trunk utility charge. 
    Each newly created residential lot or nonresidential site plan approved shall be responsible to pay trunk sewer fee, trunk water fee, and stormwater fee that are established by ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.53; Ord. No. 75-05, 6-22-1975; Ord. No. 03-39, 9-29-2003) 
Sec. 117-619. - Storm sewers. 
    In an area not having municipal storm sewer trunk, the applicant shall be responsible, before platting, to provide for a stormwater disposal plan in accordance with the city's comprehensive drainage plan without damage to properties outside the platted area and said stormwater disposal plan shall be submitted to the city engineer, who shall report to the council on the feasibility of the plan presented. No plat shall be approved before an adequate stormwater disposal plan is presented and approved by the city engineer and council. The use of dry wells for the purpose of stormwater disposal is prohibited. In areas where an outlet for stormwater does not exist and the developer is unable to negotiate a drainageway with adjacent landowners, they may petition the city to construct a drainage outlet. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.54; Ord. No. 75-05, 6-22-1975) 
Sec. 117-620. - Election by city to install improvements. 
    As stated in section 117-615(f), the subdivider may elect to construct the improvements at his own expense and without city participation in the expense. However, the city reserves the right to elect to install all or any part of the improvements required under the provisions of this chapter pursuant to Minn. Stats. ch. 429. If the city elects to install the improvements, the developer shall post a cash escrow or letter of credit guaranteeing payment of the assessments. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.55; Ord. No. 75-05, 6-22-1975) 
Sec. 117-621. - Subsurface conditions. 
    The subdivider shall cause tests to be made of subsurface conditions to determine the nature and extent of subsurface soil, rock and water. The location and results of said tests shall be made available to the city. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.56; Ord. No. 75-05, 6-22-1975) 
Sec. 117-622. - Sidewalks and pedestrian ways. 
(a)  All sidewalks and pedestrian ways required by the city shall be constructed of a four-inch concrete placed on a four-inch gravel base. Grades shall be as approved by the city engineer. Sidewalks shall be placed in the public right-of-way one foot from the property line and shall be a width designated by the city. 
(b)  Construction of trailways. All accessible bikeway/walkway trailways shall be constructed of a minimum two-inch bituminous mat on a two-inch gravel base. Grades and specifications shall be as approved by the city engineer. All paved trailways shall be of an eight-foot width with two-foot graded shoulders. All horse and wilderness trailways shall be graded to a minimum four-foot width and surfaced as determined by the park and recreation commission. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.57; Ord. No. 75-05, 6-22-1975; Ord. No. 93-01, 3-1-1993) 
Sec. 117-623. - Public utilities. 
(a)  In all residential zoned subdivisions, all telephone, electric and gas service lines shall be placed underground within dedicated public ways or recorded easements in such manner as not to conflict with other underground services. All underground installation of service lines within street rights-of-way shall be completed in a manner that will not disturb street surfacing. Upon completion of the installation of underground service lines in dedicated public ways, a tracing and two copies of plans and specifications showing the completed installation shall be filed with the zoning administrator. 
(b)  All utility poles, except those providing street lighting, shall be placed in rear lot line easements where feasible. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.58; Ord. No. 8, 4-17-1972; Ord. No. 75-05, 6-22-1975) 
Sec. 117-624. - Trunk storm drainage assessments. 
    In all drainage districts in which the city has installed or is in the process of installing trunk drainage facilities, any subdivision or re-subdivision of any lot or parcel will not be permitted until the subdivider pays or agrees to pay the trunk storm drainage charge. The amount of the storm drainage charge shall be the city's cost of the storm drainage improvement plus an increased amount of inflationary costs as determined by the construction cost index. The initial storm drainage improvement charge shall be set by a separate ordinance for each of the city's drainage districts. 
(Code 1978, § 9.50.59; Ord. No. 85-11, 2-9-1986) 
Sec. 117-625. - Council discretion to set financial guarantees. 
    Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in article III, sections 117-615 through 117-624, the city council may waive any subdivider or developer required financial security or length of special assessment repayment requirements described in said article III in lieu of alternative financial security or special assessment repayment requirements that the city council finds to be adequate to guarantee payment of any subdivider or developer obligations required in said article III for commercial, industrial, and public/quasi-public projects. Said waiver shall only apply to city constructed private improvements assessed back to benefitted properties and private improvements. 
(Ord. No. 11-04, § 1, 4-12-2011)
